entry.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
entry.summary:
The recent discussion on the Bitcoin Development Mailing List suggests a strategic approach to safeguarding Bitcoin against quantum threats through a phased implementation plan. The conversation, initiated by conduition, outlines a proposal to address vulnerabilities in the Bitcoin network susceptible to quantum attacks by introducing temporary restrictions rather than permanent blocks on transactions involving vulnerable coins. This method revolves around locking these coins until a future block height X, determined to be 5-10 years in the future, at which point they would become spendable again using enhanced cryptographic proofs.
A significant aspect of this strategy is the flexibility it offers in terms of deployment and adaptation to unforeseen advancements in quantum computing or the development of countermeasures. Specifically, the proposal allows for the merging of phases B and C—if conditions permit—into a single deployment, thus streamlining the process. Moreover, the idea addresses concerns regarding potential loss of funds due to the blocking of transactions to and from vulnerable addresses by making the blocking temporary. This approach not only mitigates the risk of confiscation but also leaves room for future solutions that could enable the recovery of funds without necessitating a hard fork of the Bitcoin protocol.
Further complicating this issue are Pay-to-Quantum-Resistant-Hash (P2QRH) addresses, which introduce unique challenges and considerations within the proposed framework. The discussion raises critical questions about how these addresses, particularly those with exposed EC spending conditions, would be treated across the different phases. The consensus leans towards imposing restrictions on all EC spending during phase B, irrespective of the script type. This uniform restriction aims to protect users’ funds until more secure quantum-resistant mechanisms are deployed in phase C.
To navigate the complexities introduced by P2QRH addresses and ensure their security against quantum attacks, the proposal suggests standardizing P2QRH address derivation and encouraging the adoption of addresses that include at least one post-quantum spending path. This would involve implementing hybrid signature schemes within the P2QRH script, combining traditional EC signatures with post-quantum signatures to facilitate a secure transition period until the network can fully adopt quantum-resistant protocols.
This dialogue underscores the Bitcoin community's proactive stance on quantum threats and highlights the collaborative effort to develop and refine strategies that balance security, usability, and forward compatibility. By considering the implications of quantum computing advancements on cryptocurrency security and adopting a phased approach to cryptographic upgrades, the community aims to safeguard Bitcoin’s integrity and user assets against future technological shifts.
